text: [Music]
we're semi-finalists for the new Venture
competition so we have a lot to put
together for the pitch and uh one piece
is making sure that our financial model
works so I met with Lee Carter this
model is obviously very well thought out
and and the way you describe it I can
understand that your assumptions come
from somewhere but then he asked me a
question that we get all the time are
you really trying to make prisons a
school um because that just sounds
controversial but school is generally a
good thing if you are like disadvantaged
and just want to reset are you now going
to try to go to prison how do you kind
of defend these kind of social questions
to the point of will people like
purposely commit crimes to go into
prison that already happens you
basically just have communities where
like you like you serve your time the
idea of detainment so so you have to
stay inside the facility you can't live
with your family all these things are
still in place and that is often um
underestimated as a form of punishment
communicating our vision with a wide
range of people is an important part of
moving reset forward we have to sell our
vision to philanthropic funders
community members government as well as
people who spent time in prison and
their families so we're bringing on
people like James who's a community
activist to help us hone our message
James spent several years in prison but
he also worked as a corrections officer
so he's teaching us how to talk about
the problem and how to motivate people
around the solution James told us the
story about being at a PTA meeting where
a proposition had been made to launch a
halfway house in the community it was in
a few blocks from three different
schools and so they organized meetings
to petition against it there was so much
resistance to it from the community but
the Turning Point came when James said
if as a community you know you have two
people Mike and Joe Mike has been able
to come out and given an opportunity to
move on with his life and Joe hasn't
been given that opportunity who do you
really want to come in contact with in
your community and by the end of that
meeting you had teachers volunteer for
how they could come to the halfway house
give classes and you know we have so
many things going on right now there's a
new Venture competition semi-finals
we're also heading to California at the
end of this month to meet with
government officials and some
philanthropic funders and now we're
creating a pilot program which is a
model designed for about 60 people so
Ursula and Joyce started out as student
advisers but we've recently brought them
on as full members of the team
specifically to help us further develop
the education component like does it
make sense to invest a lot in two years
of academic investment if they're not
going to get a GED not every student
will be able to pass a GED after two
years that's for sure but we want to
work we want to get them the best
credential that they can get now we're
thinking about mobilizing the community
in the startup world in the business
school you often talk about the minimum
viable product and quickly getting your
product out to Market quickly getting
customer feedback bring new model into
this is a difficult situation because
it's not something that we can test the
consequences of our work are huge we
actually have custody over people's
lives for a chunk of time the ultimate
test is when it happens
